RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 

 In its state program on poverty reduction and sustainable development for 2006–2015,1 
2. 
the Government of Azerbaijan committed to improving access to basic services. Considering the 
importance  of  safe  drinking  water  supply  and  sanitation  (WSS),  the  state  program  is  targeting 
improved  WSS  coverage  and  service  quality  by  2015.  This  includes  100%  coverage  with 
24-hour water supply in Baku and 80%–85% coverage in secondary towns and villages.  
 
3. 
 Given  the  magnitude  of  WSS  investment  requirements  and  the  scale  of  related  policy

sequenced  interventions  linked  with  reforms.  The  Government  requested  that  the  Asian

Performance Indicators and Analysis 

1. 

Economic, Demographic, and Poverty Profile 

Azerbaijan's  economy  declined  immediately  after  its  independence  from  the  Soviet 
4. 
Union in 1991. By 1995, its gross domestic product (GDP) had dropped by about 63% from its 
pre-independence level. However, due to development of its oil industry, the GDP grew steadily 
between 2000 and 2008 by about 10% annually, and the share of oil and gas production of the 
GDP increased from about 27% in 2000 to about 52% in 2008. While non-oil outputs also grew 
at  about  10%  annually,  the  non-oil  sector’s  share  of  GDP  has  remained  relatively  low.  The 
Government has recognized that improving infrastructure sectors, including WSS, is as critical 
for expanding the non-oil sector as it is for improving living standards among its population.  
 
5. 
Of Azerbaijan's 8.2 million people, about 52% live in urban areas. The average annual 
population growth rate for both urban and rural areas has remained steady at about 0.7% since 
2001. Baku, the capital and largest city, has a population of about 2.1 million, followed by Ganja 
(310,000)  and  Sumgayit  (270,000).  There  are  also  11  major  cities  with  populations  above 
50,000 and 28 secondary towns with 20,000–50,000 people. 
 
6. 
Poverty  levels  have  declined  from  an  estimated  49.0%  of  the  country’s  population  in 
2001  to  about  13.2%  in  2009.  Although  Baku  has  the  greatest  number  of  poor  people, 
secondary towns have higher incidences of poverty. Furthermore, rural areas and small towns 
suffer  from  unreliable  supplies  of  energy,  water,  and  gas,  and  they  often  lack  access  to  basic 
education and health services.

10. 
The  current  institutional  setup  is  complex,  as  several  institutions  have  overlapping 
oversight  functions.  They  include  (i)  the  State  Property  Company  under  the  cabinet  of

economics and pricing; and (iii) the Ministry of Health, which is responsible for monitoring water 
quality.  Consequently,  overall  sector  performance  is  not  well  monitored  or  documented.  The 
sector needs a leading policy oversight body with sufficient authority to monitor performance, to 
ensure  that  funds  provided  to  AZERSU  and  SAWMA  are  well  spent,  and  to  improve  service 
delivery.3

A. 

Economic and Financial Analyses 

The  economic  and  financial  analysis  was  carried  out  on  the  tranche  1  project.  For  the 
70. 
financial  analysis,  the  weighted  average  cost  of  capital  was  estimated  at  2.47%,  the  financial 
internal  rate  of  return  in  the  base  case  ranged  between  4.5%  and  5.5%,  and  the  financial  net 
present  value  in  the  base  case  ranged  from  $14.9  million  to  $15.0  million.  The  economic 
analysis  indicates  that  the  project  is  economically  viable,  with  the  economic  internal  rate  of 
return  (EIRR)  exceeding  the  economic  opportunity  cost  of  capital  in  all  cases.  The  economic 
opportunity  cost  of  capital  was  assumed  at  12%,  the  EIRRs  in  the  base  case  range  between 
18.0%  and  20.8%,  and  the  economic  net  present  value  in  the  base  case  ranged  from  $7.55 
million to $7.63 million. The resulting benefit–cost ratios for the tranche 1 project range between 
1.38  and  1.54,  also  denoting  feasibility.  Economic  benefits  were  derived  from  analysis  of 
willingness-to-pay surveys. Sensitivity analysis conducted to test the robustness of the financial 
sustainability and economic viability of subcomponents when subject to change (a 20% increase 
in capital cost, 20% increase in operation and maintenance cost, 20% reduction in benefits, and 
1-year  delay  in  benefits)  indicate  that,  in  all  cases,  subcomponent  financial  internal  rates  of 
return  surpass  the  weighted  average  cost  of  capital,  and  EIRRs  surpass  the  economic

The  Investment  Program  faces  several  implementation  risks.  The  following  key  risks 

81. 
have been discussed with the Government and mitigation measures agreed.  
 
Potential  Shortfall  in  Contractors.  The  Government  has  recently  signed  two  large 
82. 
projects  with  the  World  Bank  for  WSS  in  43  towns  and  with  Japan  International  Cooperation 
Agency for 10 towns. With the commencement of the Investment Program, severe shortage of 
civil works contractors is expected,  which may  delay implementation. To mitigate  this risk, the 
Investment  Program  includes  (i)  large  international  competitive  bidding  contracts  to  attract 
international contracting firms; (ii) advance procurement actions, already undertaken, to ensure 
that  works  are  commenced  shortly  after  loan  approval;  and  (iii)  incentive  provisions  in  the 

19 

 

 contractors'  contracts  to  expedite  implementation  and,  by  timely  completion,  enable  the 
contractors to apply for new contracts under the Investment Program. 
 
83. 
Limited  Executing  Agency  Capacity.  AZERSU  and  SAWMA  are  also  the  EAs  for  all 
other  donor-funded  projects.  They  lack  the  capacity  to  administer  a  large  portfolio  of  existing 
multimillion-dollar  projects.  Therefore,  implementation  is  likely  to  suffer  and  to  experience 
delays. To mitigate this risk, the Investment Program includes program management facilities, 
comprising  teams  of  international  and  national  consultants,  who  will  provide  technical  and 
management support to the EAs.  
 
84. 
Lack  of  Executing  Agency  Autonomy.  At  present,  AZERSU  and  SAWMA  are 
constrained  on  making  independent  decisions  on  SuKana  and  JSC  staffing;  procurement  of 
works, goods, and services; and financial transactions. This may result in implementation delays 
and restrict much-needed capacity development of SuKanals and JSCs. The Government has 
committed  to  streamlining  the  approval  process  by  allowing  more  autonomy  to  AZERSU  and 
SAWMA for implementing the Investment Program.  
 
85. 
Lack  of  Beneficiary  Participation.  The  EAs’  inability  to  reach  out  to  the  community, 
create awareness, and elicit support may create customer dissatisfaction, lack of their support 
during implementation, and hence delay implementation of the Investment Program. This risk is 
mitigated through a well-designed public outreach program that will ensure that beneficiaries are 
educated on the benefits and provide adequate support during implementation.  
 
86. 
Poor  Maintenance  of  Assets  after  Completion. Lack of EAs’ foresight and long-term 
commitment to build SuKanal and JSC staff capacity on technical, financial, and administrative 
matters is likely to affect the quality of service delivery. This risk is mitigated through program 
management facility input and a twinning program designed to guide SuKanal and JSC staff in 
asset maintenance, financial management, and service delivery.

Developmental Challenges  

6. 
Growth and Poverty Reduction. Azerbaijan is one of fastest growing economies in the 
world. Real gross domestic product (GDP) growth averaged 20.2% in 2004–2008, supported by 
surging crude oil production and exports. The gross national product per capita rose to $6,142 
in 2008 from $390 per capita in 1995. This rapid growth is mainly attributed to developments in 
the  oil  industry,  which  accounts  for  almost  one  third  of  Azerbaijan’s  GDP.  Oil  sector  growth 
spurred growth in transport, communications, and services. On the production side, growth was 
led  by  construction,  services,  and  agriculture.  Construction  output  expanded  by  12%  in  2008 
largely  in  secondary  towns  and  rural  areas,  residential  and  office  centers  across  the  country, 
and transport. Non-oil GDP grew at almost 16% in 2008, the highest rate of growth in the past 5 
years.  
 
7. 
Unsurprisingly,  Azerbaijan’s  growth  prospects  are  closely  linked  to  oil  prices.  GDP 
growth  is  projected  to  fall  to  8.0%  in  2009  and  further  to  6.7%  in  2010,  reflecting  relatively 
modest growth in the hydrocarbon sector. Growth in crude oil and natural gas exports will also 
slow.  With  foreign  investments  declining  in  the  oil  sector,  public  investment  will  become  the 
single  largest  source  of  growth  over  the  medium  term,  accounting  for  about  60%  of  total 
investments.  In  2009,  public  spending  expansion  will  moderate  to  around  15%  versus  an 
average  of  65%  in  the  past  3 years.  Of  concern  is  the  likelihood  that  direct  transfers  from  the 
State Oil Fund of Azerbaijan Republic will become the key source revenues for the state budget 
in 2009, and it is likely that this fund will be the largest nontax contributor for annual budgetary 
expenditure.  
 
The  Government  seeks  to  build  upon  the  opportunities  provided  by  its  oil  revenue,  as

9. 
Poverty levels have declined from an estimated 49% of the country’s population in 2001 
to about 13.2% in 2009. Poverty is higher in urban areas. Baku has the highest number of poor

(ii) they must obtain smaller quantities of water from vendors, often paying 10 times above what 
high-income households pay.

quality and efficiency of water service delivery declined in Azerbaijan due to poor management 
and  inadequate  investment.  The  existing  WSS  systems  are  over  50  years  old.  Water  supply 
sources are in a poor state of repair, and other modes of supply (e.g., through private vendors)

nearest watercourses. Poor sanitation and leaking sewers are creating serious health risks and

Level  and  Quality  of  Sector  Services.  Water  supply  is  intermittent  and  of  limited 
quantity.  The  water  quality  is  poor,  with  high  levels  of  silt.  Many  consumers  buy  water  from 
private vendors to augment their supply. Sewerage systems are failing, and pipes are clogged 
and  broken.  During  heavy  rains,  raw  sewage  floods  the  streets  and  house  compounds,  and 
existing  treatment  facilities  do  not  operate.  River  pollution  increases,  and  stagnant  sewage 
threatens  health  conditions.  Data  on  drinking  water  quality  in  Azerbaijan  are  scant  due  to 
inadequate  monitoring  and  record-keeping  practices.  While  some  reports  indicate  that 
waterborne  diseases,  such  as  bacterial  dysentery,  parasitic  infections,  typhoid,  and  viral 
hepatitis,  spread  in  Azerbaijan  during  the  1990s,  official  health  statistics  indicate  that  the 
incidence of these diseases is declining.

(town WSS agencies) and joint stock companies (JSCs) is poor. Although SuKanals and JSCs 
are self-financing agencies in principle, they are unable to recover tariffs directly due to the poor 
condition of infrastructure and related services. For nonroutine repairs, SuKanals and JSCs rely

Reform  Agenda. The WSS sector's reform agenda will (i) ensure service sustainability

strengthened  management  measures,  introducing  performance-based  service  contracts,  and 
managing  scales  of  operations  by  clustering  local  governments  where  possible;  (iii)  improve

maintenance;  (iii)  enhanced  cost  recovery  through  metering,  billing,  and  collecting  tariffs; 
(iv) increased efficiency for timely processing of effective WSS projects; (v) asset management; 
(vi) introducing a performance benchmarking system; and (vii) a twinning arrangement with an 
external  WSS  utility  to  support  capacity  development.  The  Investment  Program  also  includes 
program management support to help with (i) gender, safeguards, governance, legal, financial, 
and administrative matters; (ii) design works for subsequent tranches; and (iii) general training

benefit–cost  and  sensitivity  analyses  were  carried  out.  The  economic  benefit–cost  analysis 
compares the calculated economic internal rate of return (EIRR) with the economic opportunity 
cost  of  capital  (EOCC),  assumed  to  be  12%.  With  an  EIRR  greater  than  an  EOCC,  the 
subproject  proposal  is  deemed  economically  feasible.  A  sensitivity  analysis  was  conducted  to 
see  the  effects  of  certain  adverse  conditions  on  system  capital  investment  and  operation  and 
maintenance costs, revenue generation, and overall subproject viability. The analysis uses the 
domestic price numeraire, as benefits are nontradable in nature. The analysis was undertaken 
at constant mid-2008 price levels and assesses the subproject effects over a 30-year period. 
 
3. 
Economic  Rationale  and  Goals.  The  subproject  rationale  results  from  the  increasing 
concern  over  the  deteriorating  water  supply  and  sanitation  (WSS)  conditions  in  towns  and 
communities,  mainly  resulting  from  insufficient  funds  and  system  mismanagement.  Without 
urgent  investments  to  pursue  the  long-term  objective  of  providing  sufficient  and  secure  WSS 
services,  negative  impacts  on  the  health  of  the  poor  and  their  economic  condition  would  only 
tend to nullify any limited effort already undertaken. The Investment Program is considered high 
priority by the Government of Azerbaijan and is well integrated with other investment planning 
activities in the sector. 
 
4. 
Selection  Approach. The subprojects were selected based on the sector development 
plan and road map for the Investment Program (Appendix 2).3 The selection process required (i) 
consistency  with  demand,  based  on  community  willingness  to  participate  and  contribute;  (ii) 
least-cost  approach  of  meeting  effective  demand  in  terms  of  location,  scale,  scope,  and 
appropriate technology; and (iii) economic benefits to exceed economic costs. Preference was 
also  given  to  communities  with  higher  water-related  health  risks  and  to  multiple  communities 
served by single integrated systems. 
 
5.

supply  of  good-quality  potable  water  to  the  towns  of  Goychay  and  Nakhchivan.  The  physical 
works comprise WSS networks. The local distribution network will include metered connections.

8. 
Water  Supply  Situation.  Prior  to  and  without  the  tranche  1  project,  over  50%  of 
households  in  the  subproject  towns  relied  on  alternative  water  either  through  tankers,  bottled, 
collected,  or  pumped  from  distant  irrigation  canals,  springs,  and  rivers.  With  the  tranche  1 
project,  piped  water  will  replace  all  alternative  supplies  from  these  sources,  which  will  now 
comprise  nonincremental  demand.  The  existing  water  systems  in  the  two  subprojects  have 
recently undergone improvement since initial investment to increase supply coverage to about 
80%  in  the  central  districts,  but  large  areas  outside  the  town  centers  are  yet  to  see 
development.  However,  low-quality  supplies  still  afflict  served  and  unserved  populations.  The 
supply situation is projected to rise with the population growth rate and to increase annually to 
reach the design target population served at 90% by 2013 (year 5). 
 
9. 
Existing  demand  averages  150–200  liters  per  capita  per  day  for  house  connections. 
Demand  is  based  on  existing  reports  and  actual  survey,  and  is  assumed  to  improve  with  the 
subprojects  in  place.  In  the  selected  program  towns,  households  without  connections  could 
spend  about  2–4  hours  daily  covering  a  distance  of  500–1,500  meters  to  collect  water  from 
unsafe  sources,  such  as  open  irrigation  canals  and  unprotected  surface  water.  Poor 
maintenance  of  the  existing  piped  systems—due  to  lack  of  funds  resulting  from  inadequate

Background  and  Objectives.  The  tranche  1  project  under  the  Water  Supply  and 
Sanitation Investment Program (the Investment Program) will cover subprojects in Goychay and 
Nakhchivan.  In  these  towns,  the  existing  water  supply  and  sanitation  system  is  over  50  years

A.  Links to the National Poverty Reduction Strategy and Country Partnership Strategy  
An  8-year,  $600  million  program  under  a  multitranche  financing  facility,  the  Investment  Program  will  fund  basic  urban 
infrastructure  improvements  in  secondary  towns  within  Azerbaijan  and  the  Nakhchivan  Autonomous  Republic.  The

initiatives  to  improve  service  delivery,  are  consistent  with  the  key  strategic  goals  of  Azerbaijan’s  state  program  on  poverty 
reduction and sustainable development.a The Investment Program will uphold the state program’s goals by improving public 
infrastructure, developing sustainable environmental management, and improving public administration and good governance. 
The Investment Program also aims to reduce the 13% poverty level in the towns in conjunction with the state program target 
goals of an overall poverty level of 8% and extreme poverty elimination by 2015. Also, in accordance with the state program, 
the Investment Program will promote the participation and employment of women in decision-making roles ranging from local 
to executive levels and will reduce the gap in indicators for female and male employment. 
 
The Investment Program will focus on providing approximately 500,000 persons with access to improved water and sanitation 
services.  With  direct  access  to  basic  services,  the  poor  in  the  region  will  be  able  to  productively  use  the  available  time  in 
gainful  employment,  thereby  alleviating  poverty  levels.  Improvements  in  the  quality  of  water  and  disposal  of  treated 
wastewater will lead to public health improvements and reductions in the burden of waterborne diseases, treatment costs, and 
productive losses, the impact of which is predominantly felt by the poor. Women, especially poor women, will benefit from the 
reduction  in  the  time  and  energy  spent  in  fetching  and  storing  water,  and  in  the  work  associated  with  cleaning  and  family 
health care. 
B.  Poverty Analysis                                 Targeting Classification: General Intervention 
Poverty remains relatively high in Azerbaijan. According to a 2008 speech given by the chairperson of statistics, on the basis 
of  consumption  per  capita,  an  estimated  13.2%  of  the  population  lives  below  the  poverty  line  and  2.0%  live  in  extreme 
poverty. However, in 2003, the poverty level was 45.0% while the extreme poverty level was 9.6%. The national poverty line is 
estimated as the cost of a minimum consumption basket, calculated on the basis of per capita monthly minimum consumption 
norms.  The  unit  of  observation  for  poverty  statistics  is  the  individual.  Analysis  of  house  budget  survey  data  for  2002–2005 
shows that there is a small difference in the poverty rates for urban and rural areas. The exception is between Baku and the 
rest of the country; the poverty incidence Baku has been declining at a faster rate than for the rest of the population. There 
are  also  regional  differences  in  poverty  levels,  with  the  Nakhchivan  Autonomous  Republic  and  Upper  Shirvan  having  the 
highest levels. Furthermore, internally displaced persons (refugees) have higher poverty levels than the rest of the population. 
In  2007,  the  average  poverty  incidence  among  these  persons  was  37%  (compared  to  16%  for  the  country).  The  highest 
poverty incidence among internally displaced persons in 2003 was observed in rural settlements (61%), while in urban areas, 
the poverty level for internally displaced persons was approximately 42%. In contrast, there are no significant differences in 
the poverty levels for men and women. 

To deal with poverty issues, approximately 30 types of social benefits for 13 categories of vulnerable groups are included in

Social Benefits (2006). 

There  is  a  significant  level  of  uneven  economic  development  in  Azerbaijan.  The  wealthiest  10%  of  the  population  control

A.  Findings of Social Analysis  
The  average  monthly  household  income  for  2007  in  rural  and  urban  areas  was  AZN110  ($136).  As  of  2008,  the  minimum 
salary  wage  per  month  was  AZN60  ($74).  The  2007  unemployment  rate  for  Azerbaijan  was  6.5%,  with  more  women 
registered  as  unemployed.  In  program  towns,  the  majority  of  men  work  in  agriculture,  while  the  women  work  in  lower-paid 
public sectors including teaching, medicine, and nursing. There is a relatively decent representation of health care and school 
facilities within the project towns. 

In  Azerbaijan,  approximately  60%  of  the  Baku–Absheron  region  and  46.5%  of  the  towns  and  villages  have  access  to  an 
uninterrupted,  good-quality  water  supply.  In  program  towns,  approximately  35%  of  the  towns  have  access  to  a  piped  water 
supply system. Of the percentage of people that have water supply, none receive a continuous 24-hour supply, some lacking 
water for several days. On average, 35% of people obtain water from water trucks, and 18% must walk to water sources with 
distances ranging from 150 meters to a maximum of 3 kilometers. Water sources other than water trucks include standpipes 
and private wells. About 75% of the population is dissatisfied with the water quality and pressure. Between 3% and 23% have 
fallen ill with short-term stomach sicknesses due to poor-quality water within program towns. 

Within  the  towns  surveyed,  15%  of  the  population  has  sewage  collection.  Most  households  use  pit  latrines  and  some  use 
septic tanks, which often overflow. Also, households discharge sewage directly to the roadside channels that line the streets 
and flow through the towns. During periods of rain, sewage overflows into the streets and on public property. Also, there are 
many blockages and overflows that often affect residential areas. Approximately 85% of respondents surveyed have sewage 
problems on their property. There is currently no  wastewater treatment in most towns. Although in many towns, there  were 
plans to build conventional wastewater treatment plants during Soviet times, the plants were never constructed.  

Water  was  perceived  as  the  highest  priority  for  all  the  towns  surveyed;  sanitation  in  all  towns  was  also  recognized  as  a 
priority.  The  general  awareness  of  sanitary  standards  is  lacking  in  the  towns.  Many  surveyed  did  not  realize  that  the  open 
sewage channels were linked with malaria and other waterborne diseases. 

About 45%–80% of locals were willing to pay for a 24-hour, good quality water supply and sanitation collection services. Most 
would  be  willing  to  pay  AZN2.0–AZN5.5  ($2.50–$6.80)  per  month  for  water  supply  or  according  to  what  the  water  meter 
reads.  Similarly,  most  would  be  willing  to  pay  AZN5.0  ($6.20)  per  month  for  wastewater  collection.  They  were,  therefore, 
willing to pay a maximum of approximately 10% of their salaries for basic water and wastewater services. 

The  potential  primary  beneficiaries  of  the  Investment  Program  are  the  urban  populations  of  towns.  The  urban  populations 
include refugees and displaced persons. Between 100 and 6,000 refugees and 20 to 1,600 internally displaced persons have 
residence in the project towns. Under the Investment Program, basic services will be provided to all refugees and internally 
displaced  persons.  The  Investment  Program  will  also  provide  an  opportunity  to  strengthen  the  role  of  women  in  the 
community, thereby raising their status. It is expected that women will become empowered by being involved in the local town 
water users’ associations and in decision-making positions within the implementing and executing agencies. The Investment 
Program  will  also  lessen  the  burden  on  women  as  the  main  collectors  of  water  and  as  nurses  for  the  sick  affected  by 
unsanitary conditions. The subprojects will provide employment opportunities for residents, both in the construction or repair 
of water supply and sanitation systems, as well as in the management of the systems. Overall, time will be saved, and better 
health will improve the productive capacity of the whole population.

Key Issues  

Women are most frequently the household members who are most affected by the lack of adequate, clean, and safe water. 
Adult  women  are  the  main  collectors  of  water  when  there  is  no  individual  house  connection  (in  approximately  65%  of  the

The purposes of the Water Supply and Sanitation Investment Program (the Investment
